and I should be delighted to make it available in thirty minute
packages for distribution by the net to any stations which wart it.
It may not do the superintellectual job which we need to do in
large measure, but I believe it will have great popular appeal
far many of our stations and is worthy, at least, of the considera¬
tion of the program acceptance committee.
And speaking of committees, there are a few new ones
which I shall appoint within a few days. Until I have had time
to completely revamp the committee setup, I shall ask that all
committees appointed by Si continue to function until notified
of any changes. On the whole, I think the committee setup was
excellent and only a few changes will be made. By action of
the Board on Thursday morning in Minneapolis the new president,
Seymour Siegel, and George Piobst are to constitute our committee
on international affairs. It occurs to me that that might be
a good committee to handle the Fulbright Scholarships.
I hope you did not misunderstand my question concerning
the relationship of the president and the headquarters operation.
I have no concern with meddling in any branch of the operation
that is running well and I congratulate you on the efficiency with
which our headquarters operation is functioning. I am confident
that it will continue to so function and have no interest in
taking on any responsibilities concerning it other than those
which would normally accrue to the office of president. I
trust you will observe the good practice of sending me carbons
of significant correspondence - blind copies or acknowledged
copies - so I can keep up with any significant activities
from headquarters office.
The revised constitution was approved by action of
the Saturday afternoon Board meeting, but Si announced that it
would go into effect thirty days from that date. I do not know
whether this is the necessary waiting period or not, but it is
still good business. I can see no reason, however, for your
delay in sending out notices to prospective members under the
new constitution^^iiiMHB^ and would suggest that you proceed
to do so. furthermore, I think you should proceed with plans
for new printing of the new constitution. A committee was
appointed to make a revision of our total dues structure with
Frank Schooley as chairman (you probably have the names of the
other members of that committee in your notes). The dues struc¬
ture should not become a permanent part of the constitution nor
bylaws, however, but should be printed as a separate flyer.
